instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: When I connect this board, it tries to go on and gets back to stand by, when that happens <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulses. So I can´t get <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> because of that. Call for a dead cpu?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
What about other voltages and signals?
Any history available?
Did you try SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing too... I followed the trace to <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is not being created, it pulses and then goes to 0v...changed <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>, no change...
History... this came in because keyboard and trackpad weren´t working... it went out as a no fixable because it was the PCH, now the customer thinks I did something because it is not turning on... the customer was using it with an external kb and mouse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So when the problem appeared?
Check all you did on the board; maybe knocked off component.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I gave the computer working to the customer, it returned because it doesn´t turn on anymore... and have problems with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> which I need to have also I don´t get <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses, then <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> pulse too.
All S3 and S0 voltages should also pulse, check that; don't forget pages 57 & 58.
Check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
What about <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
so I narrowed down to
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>, when <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> is removed, the computer tries to turn on, it even goes up to .380A... I replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> just in case, but stll the same...
smc bypass tries tu turn on the machine, but cant make it... 
when <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> is removed, all the voltages are OK but <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get 3V at pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, w/o <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR>?
It should pulse at least, if <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> is present.

You can't get <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, if PCH doesn't receive <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
With <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> removed
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> PIN 3 = 3.4
when <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> present
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> PIN 3 = Pulse of .030v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You should get higher peak pulse; check diode mode to ground at  <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> .
Do you get 3V there in SMC bypass?

Any pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?
Also check at <SIGNAL>VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Diode Mode on PIN 2 <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> =.723
In SMC bypass mode the board tries to run getting to .290A and then drop back to .01 A
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses to .008v
<SIGNAL>VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> small pulse up to .530v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Don't get higher pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> in SMC bypass mode?
Don't forget to solder <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
When <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> is in place I get .10A and goes back to standby
in smc bypass mode I get to .14A and goes back to standby
with <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> in place <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses to .130v in smc bypass mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PULSING <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
